content: The "Fusion Center Enhancement Act of 2015" is cited as the short title. The Department of Homeland Security Fusion Center Partnership Initiative is amended under Section 210A of the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The Department of Homeland Security Fusion Center Partnership Initiative is renamed as the `Department of Homeland Security Fusion Center Partnership Initiative' under the Fusion Center Enhancement Act of 2015. It involves coordinating with federal departments and agencies to provide support and intelligence to fusion centers in the National Network of Fusion Centers. The Department of Homeland Security Fusion Center Partnership Initiative, now known as the Department of Homeland Security Fusion Center Partnership Initiative under the Fusion Center Enhancement Act of 2015, provides intelligence support and assistance to the National Network of Fusion Centers. This includes integrating fusion centers into the information sharing environment, supporting their maturation and sustainment, maximizing federal resource support efficiency, offering analytic and reporting advice, and reviewing relevant information for incorporation into the Department's own data. The Department of Homeland Security Fusion Center Partnership Initiative supports the National Network of Fusion Centers by disseminating information, facilitating communication with federal agencies, providing expertise on department resources, coordinating training and technical assistance, and ensuring support for fusion centers. The National Network of Fusion Centers is a national priority in homeland security grant guidance. Each fusion center must have approved privacy and civil rights policies. Coordination of suspicious activity reports and sharing of security information are key responsibilities of the Department of Homeland Security. The curr_chunk discusses the development and dissemination of best practices for staffing at fusion centers in the National Network of Fusion Centers. It also mentions the Secretary's determination of appropriate duties for fusion centers. The Under Secretary for Intelligence and Analysis ensures fusion centers have access to homeland security information sharing systems and deploys Department personnel to support them in line with the Department's mission and statutory limits. Department personnel may include various roles. The Under Secretary for Intelligence and Analysis negotiates memoranda of understanding between the Department and state or local governments, in coordination with fusion centers, for the exchange of information. This includes various roles such as intelligence officers, analysts, and liaisons from different Department components and offices. The Under Secretary for Intelligence and Analysis negotiates memoranda of understanding with state or local governments and fusion centers for information exchange, outlining categories of information, intended uses, joint product development procedures, dispute resolution processes, and necessary protections to ensure compliance with laws and policies. Information shared and personnel assigned by Department components and offices, including the Office of Intelligence and Analysis, Office of Infrastructure Protection, Transportation Security Administration, U.S. Customs and Border Protection, and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, in coordination with fusion centers in the National Network. The Under Secretary for Intelligence and Analysis coordinates with federal agencies to deploy personnel with relevant expertise to fusion centers in the National Network. The Secretary establishes criteria for sharing information and deploying personnel to support fusion centers. The Under Secretary for Intelligence and Analysis coordinates with federal agencies to deploy personnel with relevant expertise to fusion centers in the National Network, in accordance with the Department's mission and statutory limits. Updates include specifying the region of the fusion center and clarifying language regarding governments involved. The Department will utilize information to develop analysis focused on its mission. The Secretary will prioritize allocating resources to support fusion centers in border jurisdictions to enhance border security. The Department aims to enhance border security by supporting fusion centers in border jurisdictions to identify and interdict threats to homeland security. The National Network of Fusion Centers is a decentralized arrangement intended for this purpose. The National Network of Fusion Centers aims to enhance border security by leveraging the capabilities of individual State and urban area fusion centers for analysis and information sharing nationally. The Under Secretary for Intelligence and Analysis of the Department of Homeland Security is required to report on these efforts annually. The Office of Intelligence and Analysis, along with other relevant components of the Department, are working to enhance support for fusion centers in the National Network of Fusion Centers. This includes meeting the requirements specified in the Homeland Security Act of 2002. Additionally, a clerical amendment was made to the table of contents in the Act. The Department of Homeland Security Fusion Centers Initiative was passed by the House of Representatives on November 2, 2015. Any mention of the "Department of Homeland Security State, Local, and Regional Fusion Center Initiative" in laws, rules, or regulations will now be referred to as the "Department of Homeland Security Fusion Center Initiative."
